content: How can I help you today?
Honestly, I’m not really sure. My wife pushed me to come here, and I don’t know if this will really help anything. Things just feel like too much right now.

It sounds like there’s a lot weighing on you, and you’re unsure about being here today. Your willingness to start this conversation, even if you’re feeling uncertain, is a big step. What feels like “too much” right now for you?

It’s just… everything. My wife and I aren’t doing well, my son is acting out and we don’t know how to help him, and I’m worried about my daughter because I barely have time for her. I feel like I’m completely failing at keeping everything together.

That sounds incredibly overwhelming—you’re juggling a lot between your relationship, your children, and trying to support everyone while feeling stretched thin yourself. It seems like you care deeply about your family, even if it’s hard to feel like you’re meeting those expectations right now. How are you managing to cope with all of this?

Honestly, I don't think I’m managing much at all. I feel stuck. I can’t focus at work, I don’t enjoy anything I used to, and I’m just constantly stressed. It’s like I’m barely holding on, and I don’t know how to fix anything.

You’re carrying a heavy load, and feeling stuck and like you’re barely holding on sounds exhausting and discouraging. It shows how much you want to do the best for your family and yourself, even though right now it seems hard to see a way forward. What do you think needs to change for things to feel even a little bit better?

I don’t know… I feel like everything would have to change. My wife and I need to figure out how to help our son, but we’re just not seeing eye-to-eye anymore, and it’s making everything worse. I need to figure out how to be more present at work and for my daughter, but I just feel so drained all the time. I don’t even know where to start.

It sounds like there are many layers to what you’re experiencing—your relationship, parenting challenges, work stress, and feeling drained. That shows how deeply you care about each piece of your life, even if it feels overwhelming right now. You’re recognizing the areas where you’d like things to improve, even if it feels hard to know where to begin. What feels most important to focus on right now?

It’s hard to choose, but I feel like if we could figure out how to help my son, it might ease some of the tension with my wife and give me some space to breathe. But I don’t even know where to start with that. We've tried everything we can think of, and nothing seems to work. It’s just so frustrating.

It’s clear how much you care about your son and want to help him, even in the face of frustration and feeling like other efforts haven’t worked. Wanting that for him while balancing the stress it brings highlights how deeply invested you are in your family. Exploring ways to approach this differently might feel daunting, but it could also create that breathing space you’re looking for. What do you think keeps getting in the way of finding something that might work for him?

It’s tough because every time we think we’re helping, things just spiral back. He gets frustrated so easily and acts out, and I don’t know if it’s something we’re doing wrong as parents. It’s like we just can’t connect with him in the way he needs, and I feel guilty all the time for not having the answers.

It sounds like you’re carrying a lot of guilt and responsibility, questioning yourself as a parent while trying so hard to connect with your son and support him. That shows how much you care about doing what’s best for him, even when it feels frustrating and uncertain. Parenting challenges can be incredibly isolating—do you ever talk to anyone else, like a professional or trusted person, about what you’re experiencing with him?

No, not really. My wife and I have talked about it a lot, but it usually just ends up in more frustration between us. We haven’t really gone beyond that—like with a professional or anything—because I’m not sure it would actually help. Plus, it’s hard to admit that we just don’t have it figured out on our own.

Admitting it feels hard makes sense—it’s tough to acknowledge struggles, especially when you’ve been doing everything you can as parents. But sometimes reaching out for support creates new possibilities, especially when you feel stuck. It’s clear how much you care about finding the right path for your son and your family. What would make opening up to a professional feel more manageable or worth considering?

I guess if I really thought it could help my son and take some of the pressure off at home, it might be worth trying. I'm just hesitant because it feels like admitting defeat, like I’ve failed as a parent. But at the same time, I want to do whatever it takes to make things better—for him, for my wife, and for my daughter. Maybe it’s something I should consider.

The fact that you care so deeply about making things better for your family speaks volumes about your dedication—you haven’t failed as a parent; you’ve been doing your best in challenging circumstances. Sometimes seeking support isn’t about defeat but about opening up tools and solutions you may not have realized were available. Considering this is a courageous and hopeful step. Is there anything else weighing on you right now that you’d want to address before exploring what support might look like?

Though I'm hesitant, I think it's time to wrap up for now. Thank you for listening to me and guiding me through this—it means a lot. I’ll really think about seeking professional support for my son and family. Take care.
